org.xlattice.util

Class JnlpVersion

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.xlattice.util.JnlpVersion

  • public class JnlpVersion
extends java.lang.Object
    Versions for Webstart (JNLP) as specified in Sun's JSR-056, "Java Network Launching Protocol". For compatibility with JNLP, XLattice version numbers should conform to JSR 56. To improve understandability, they should conform to the stricter syntax described in the next paragraphs.

    JNLP version numbers are strings consisting of a number of parts (substrings) delimited by separators. While a number of separators must be recognized (any of ".-_"), only the dot ('.') should be used. Similarly, while this implementation will trim off leading and trailing white space, in practice version numbers should not have any. The specification permits any non-separator character to be used in the parts. However, in practice, only digits and alphabetical characters should be used. Certainly whitespace characters and non-printing characters should never be used in parts. Preferably all parts will be entirely numeric; if it seems necessary to use alphabetic characters, they should if at all possible confined to the last part.

    Author:
    Jim Dixon

    • Constructor Detail

      • JnlpVersion

        public JnlpVersion(java.lang.String s)
        Create a JNLP version from a String consisting of a number of parts separated by dot, dash, or underscore (".-_") as required by JSR 56. The initialization String is trimmed. Syntactically the initializer is part (separator part)* where the 'part' substrings consist of any characters other than the separators. JSR 56 does not prohibit modifiers, star (*) or plus (+), from appearing in the parts, but in practice they should be avoided.
        Parameters:
        s - JNLP version in String form

      • JnlpVersion

        public JnlpVersion(Version v)
        Create a JNLP version number from an XLattice version number. If the decimal part of the XLattice version number is negative, it is ignored. The build number is always ignored.

    • Method Detail

      • get

        public java.lang.String get(int n)
        Returns the Nth part of a JNLP version number.
        Parameters:
        n - zero-based index into the parts
        Returns:
        Nth part of the version, as a String

      • size

        public int size()
        The number of parts.
        Returns:
        the number of parts in the version string

      • compareParts

        protected static int compareParts(java.lang.String lhs,
               java.lang.String rhs)
        Compare two parts as numbers if possible, otherwise lexigraphically. If the first argument sorts before the second, a negative value is returned. If they are the same, zero is returned. Otherwise a positive value is returned. The arguments should not contain delimiters or separators, but there is no check on this.
        Parameters:
        lhs - first value in comparison
        rhs - second value in comparison
        Returns:
        ordering as described above

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(JnlpVersion rhs)
        Compare this to another version numerically if possible, otherwise lexigraphically. The versions have been split into parts around separators (dot, dash, underscore; ".-_") which are not themselves considered in determining ordering. If one version string has more parts than another, the shorter is in effect normalized by padding it out with "0" parts.
        Parameters:
        rhs - JNLP version being compared to
        Returns:
        the ordering described under compareParts(String, String)

      • partialMatch

        public boolean partialMatch(JnlpVersion rhs)
        Determine whether the candidate rhs version is an exact match to this version, without normalizing beyond the length of this version.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Return the original String form of the version number. Leading and trailing whitespace is trimmed off, but the separators are unchanged.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        string passed to the constructor, trimmed
